Expectation1: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation1: Roads are dry with light traffic and normal speed limits
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I had just finished my morning shift as a taxi driver, weaving through the city’s light traffic, always careful to obey every traffic law. My company expected me to drive defensively, and I prided myself on my clean record. After parking my cab, I hurried to the polling station to cast my vote. The process was smooth until a poll worker noticed my signature on the ballot envelope was smudged. She politely asked me to re-sign it, explaining that otherwise, my vote might not count. I hesitated, remembering the strict instructions from my taxi company about never signing anything twice on official documents, to avoid any suspicion of fraud or carelessness. The poll worker insisted it was necessary, but my mind raced with worry—what if this small act conflicted with the standards I was held to as a professional driver? I stood there, pen in hand, feeling the weight of both roles pressing down on me, unsure which expectation I should honor.
